importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan's successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, signaling a major advancement in the nation's space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of Pakistan's space programme activity in 2025, including the launch of three satellites this year, highlights a rapid expansion in national space capabilities and technological ambition.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, into orbit from China's Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre.
The H1 satellite is capable of detecting subtle chemical and material changes on Earth's surface, enabling applications in agriculture, water resource monitoring, and disaster response.
SUPARCO, Pakistan’s space agency, declared the launch a 'major milestone' and 'pivotal step forward' in Pakistan’s space programme.
The satellite is expected to improve national capacities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and geohazard risk identification.
The mission is part of a broader push by Pakistan to strengthen its space capabilities, with two other operational satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) already in orbit.
It may take about two months to fully calibrate and activate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational.
Pakistan highlighted the strategic partnership with China as central to this mission, citing shared goals in peaceful space exploration and socioeconomic development.
The satellite's capabilities are expected to support development initiatives like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), particularly in infrastructure planning and natural resource management.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in South Asia that has launched its first hyperspectral satellite as part of a growing space programme.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the central actor in the article, launching and operating the first hyperspectral satellite, marking a significant step in national technological and scientific advancement.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s national space agency responsible for the development and launch of the H1 satellite.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is the key organization behind the satellite launch and is credited with announcing the success and outlining the strategic benefits of the mission.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s first hyperspectral satellite, launched into orbit on October 19, 2025.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is the technological centerpiece of the article, enabling advanced Earth observation for agriculture, disaster management, and resource planning.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A space launch facility located in northwestern China, where the H1 satellite was launched.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch site underscores Pakistan’s international collaboration with China in space technology and operations.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country with which Pakistan has a strategic space partnership, including the launch of the H1 satellite from China’s launch centre.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China plays a critical role as the launch site provider, reflecting a broader strategic and technological partnership between the two nations in space exploration.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development initiative linking China’s Xinjiang province to Pakistan’s Gwadar Port.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The hyperspectral satellite data is expected to support CPEC by enabling better environmental and geohazard monitoring in infrastructure zones.

namedEntities.name: Muhammad Yousuf Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Chairman of SUPARCO, who commented on the satellite’s potential impacts in agriculture and climate resilience.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a key official providing direct insight into the societal and economic benefits of the satellite technology.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Two other satellites already in orbit and fully operational in Pakistan’s space programme.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They illustrate the broader context of Pakistan’s expanding space capabilities and provide a benchmark for H1’s future operational timeline.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a major milestone in its space programme. The satellite, capable of detecting fine material and chemical changes on Earth, will support national initiatives in agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster risk assessment. This achievement is part of a broader push by SUPARCO to expand Pakistan’s space capabilities, with two other operational satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) already in orbit. The mission strengthens Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China, particularly in the context of development projects like the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), where detailed environmental and geohazard data will be vital. Although full operational status is expected within two months, the launch signifies a transformative step toward self-reliance in Earth observation and national development.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
